p: The recognition of health co-benefits is critical to public health efforts to prevent health impacts of climate change and is fundamental to the public health goal of eliminating health inequities. Health co-benefits of policies to mitigate climate changes may be realized in the short term, while the environmental benefits may be apparent only after many years or decades [ 7]. There are many ways in which environmental interventions intended to prevent or mitigate climate change may have important health co-benefits for urban populations.
